title: 15-things-weekend-scotland-lockdown-eases
story: And as were all getting used to like taking on its new normal, we pulled together a list ofthings to do this weekend to get you out of the house.Here are the top  things to do this weekend:VISIT A CASTLE ndash CAERLAVEROCK CASTLEWhile the actual castle is currently closed, the grounds and green spaces of Caerlaverock Castle are now open for free as one of Scottish Tourismrsquosopen-air sites. The castlersquos wide moat, towered gatehouse and battlements make it look like something straight out of a fairytale.Caerlaverock CastleIn fact, the castle has been a popular filming location, featuring in films such as the Decoy Bride starring David Tenant. Gaze up at the formidable red sandstone defensive walls, unique in Britain for the triangular shape, and take in a piece of Scottish history.Caerlaverock Castle, Glencaple, Dumfries, DG RU.  .THE REAL MARY KINGrsquoS CLOSEThe Royal Mary Kingrsquos Close in Edinburgh opened back up to the public last Saturday. Located underneaththe Royal Mile, this five-star attraction features uniquely preserved th-century streets and has spent lockdown redesigning its tours to ensure the safety of staff and visitors alike ndash including preparing some exciting new tour features.The tours will run at % capacity and staff will be wearing masks and gloves where possible, maintaining a social distance at all times. The attraction has been given ldquoGood to Go status by VisitScotland, so visitors can be sure their safety is a priority. Delve into Edinburghrsquos murky history and explore places once inhabited by some of the cityrsquos most influential people.The Real Mary King Close, Warristonrsquos Close,  High Street, Edinburgh, EH PG. Tours run from am-.pm. Tickets from pound, can be booked onlineSLOANSPut down the takeaway menus and get yourself out for a good, old-fashioned sit-down, pub meal. Since  Sloans has been serving thirsty Glaswegians and this week they finally reopened their doors to the public.With a fully heated and covered outdoor courtyard, book yourself a spot outside. Or,itrsquos a little chilly and you want to stay inside, it has plenty of indoor seating on offer.Like everywhere, Sloans has made some important changes to ensure the safety of customers and employees alike, including social distancing, online bookings and contactless payments only, as well as regular cleaning and hand-sanitiser stations throughout the pub.Sloans,  Argyll Arcade,  Argyll Street, Glasgow, G BG. Monday-Sunday, noon-pm.   .THE SAINT BEER GARDENOne of the lesser known spots in St Andrews, The Saintrsquos beer garden is the perfect place to relax with a pint in the fresh air. After reopening its doors earlier this month, the Saint has put several measures in place to ensure the safety of staff and customers.These include temperature checks on arrival, as well as submitting your details for contact tracing. Booking in advance is mandatory and tables are limited to six people. But donrsquot worry ndash yoursquoll still have ample time to enjoy your drinks as you have your reservation for just less than two hours. Therersquos plenty of space to enjoy a relaxing drink not too far away from the hustle and bustle of the town centre.The Saint Bar  Kitchen,  South Street, St Andrews, KY EG.Monday-Sunday -pm.  .THE SCOTTISH GALLERYHead to the Scottish Gallery this weekend for your artistic fix! The gallery reopenedearlier this month and visitors can call or email the gallery to plan their visit ahead of time.Therersquos a host of exhibitions on show this month including Davy Brown at  ndash Brownrsquos th birthday exhibition with the galleryndash showcasing his still le and landscape painting.As well as The Edinburgh School exhibition, featuring pieces from artists associated with the Edinburgh College of Art after the First World War.The Scottish Gallery,  Dundas Street, Edinburgh, EH HZ. Tuesday-Friday am-pm and Saturday am-pm   .HIGHLAND FOLK MUSEUMIf yoursquore looking for something educational to do in the north of Scotland in the coming weeks then the Highland Folk Museum is the place to go. Theyrsquore reopening on Wednesday and will be open every Wednesday through to Sunday, with visitors needing to pre-book their visit online.The collections on display at the museum mainly reflect the social and rural way of le in the Scottish Highlands from the s all the way through to the mid-s. Some of the collections include the Agricultural Collectionand the Domestic Collection with items ranging from cooking material through heating, lighting and laundry to traditional house fittings and furniture, along with many other collections, giving you ample opportunity to learn about all aspects of the history of the Scottish Highlands.Highland Folk Museum, Kingussie Road, Newtonmore, PH AY. Wednesday-Sunday .am-pm .  .TAKE A SCENIC DRIVE ndash ABERFOYLE TO CALLANDERFor a fun activity that doesnrsquot even involve getting out of the car, this scenic drive from Aberfoyle to Callander, via the Three Lochs Forest, is a perfect weekend activity.On this quiet forest road you can venture through the woodlands of the Queen Elizabeth Forest Park, which stretches almost eight miles, taking you past three enchanting lochs ndash Lochan Reoidhte, Loch Drunkie and Loch Achray.The drive only takes about an hour and  minutes but there are several car parks on the drive, as well as picnic areas and some short trailsyou fancy a walk to stretch your legs.Access the entrance to the Three Lochs Forest Drive from the A just north of Aberfoyle . Departure point: Aberfoyle.CHECK OUT A FARMERSrsquo MARKET ndash LEITH MARKETAlthough farmersrsquo markets ed this month, they look very dferent, but are still a great day out. All traders will be at least two metres away from one another and there will be no hot food .Therersquos also no craft stalls at the moment, but therersquos plenty of fresh food for visitors to browse and purchase. Social distancing measures are being enforced and all staff are wearing masks.Leith Market Dock Place, EH LU.Open every Saturday from am-pm.HAVE A PICNIC AT ROWARDENNANThis tranquil spot on the banks of Loch Lomond is the perfect place for a summerrsquos day picnic. Take in the views of the loch and even go for a paddle at Rowardennan before you eat.Afterwards, the Ben Lomond Memorial Trail is a short, easy walk that ends at the Ben Lomond Memorial Park, which features the award-winning sculpture from artist Doug Cocker framing the peak of Ben Lomond.G AR is the nearest postcode ndash follow the signs from Drymen.CAMP AT HORGABOST CAMPSITENestled away at the south of Harris is the remote Horgabost Campsite, perfect for a weekend staycation.The views here stretch out over the water, interrupted only by the gentle rise of Taransay Island. Its remoteness makes it the perfect place to stargaze. And, being so far north, you may be able to catch a glimpse of the Northern Lights.Horgabost, Isle of Harris, Hebrides, HS HR.  .GRAB SOME AFTERNOON TEA AT THE WILLOW TEA ROOMSInspired by the works of Charles Rennie Mackintosh, the Willow Tea Rooms in Glasgow are modelled after Kate Cranstonrsquos Ingram Street Tea Rooms from the early-s and is the perfect place to indulge in some afternoon tea in style.Although booking is not mandatory, customers are encouraged to book in advanceto guarantee a table, minimise queues and prevent congestion at the entrance to the Willow. They will also be serving a reduced menu for the first few weeks while they get to grips with this new way of dining ndash but itjust gives you an opportunity to try something new! Buchanan Street, Glasgow, G HF Mon-Fri am-pm Sat am-.pm Sun am-.pm.   .VISIT A BOTANICAL GARDEN ndash DAWYCK BOTANIC GARDENDawyck Botanic Garden is a five-star garden, known for its seasonaldisplays of flowers such as snowdrops, bluebells, rhododendrons andazaleas. Surrounded by the hills of the Scottish Borders, Dawyck has an almost continental feel to its climate during the summer months allowing plants from places including China, Nepal, Japan and North America to thrive.Take a look at some of the plants on display, including Heritage Trees and blue poppies. The cafes are also open, offering a range of refreshments to take away that you can enjoy in the gardens.Dawyck Botanic Gardens, Stobo, Scottish Borders, EH JU. Open daily from am-pm. Tickets from pound. HAVE A BEACH DAY ndash ROSEISLE BEACHTrees growing down to the waterrsquos edge is not a common sight among Scotlandrsquos beaches, but trees andsand together can be found on the beach at Roseisle in Moray near Elgin. In the woodlands beside the beach, there are plenty of walks and trails to take on.Beside the sea, there are interesting historical objects, such as pillboxes and concrete blocks dating back to the Second World War. On the horizon, you can gaze upon the clfs surrounding Cromarty Firth and the long line of northern hills.Kinloss, Forres, Morayshire, IV UB.FLY A KITE ndash PETTYCUR BAYLockdown has been the perfect timeto learn new skills. If you havenrsquot already, why not make one of themkite flying ndash the ideal socially distanced activity. And Pettycur Bay in Feis a great spot to learn to kite fly.When the tide is out, therersquos a mile-and-a-half of solid beach to work with. Although kite surfers also use the beach, youcan easily kite-fly alongside. However, be careful as when the tide is in there is no beach.Pettycur Bay, Burntisland KY SB.TAKE A TRIP TO THE ZOO ndash EDINBURGH ZOOA family favourite day out, trips to the zoo are back! Edinburgh Zoohas reopened with a wide range of safety measures in place to protect visitors and staff alike, including new one-way routes and wearing face coverings in indoor areas.Visitors also must book a time slot in advance to ensure everything runs as smoothly as possible. Almost all of their indoor animal areas are open but keeper talks and public animal feeds have been postponed until further notice.Edinburgh Zoo,  Corstorphine Road, Corstorphine, Edinburgh EH TSTickets from pound. Open daily from am-pm.   .

title: Opinion  Marianne Taylor  We   re all public health guinea pigs now    but that   s just the way it has to be
story: Irsquove also started planning a wee holiday up north and have booked a hairdressersrsquo appointment. Irsquove looked out my monthly cinema pass in anticipation of re-opening around July .I appreciate not everyone feels this way, but Irsquom ready to start living again. Irsquom also ready to accept some fundamental political realities.Letrsquos face it, wersquore all just guinea pigs now, part of a radical public health experiment the likes of which has never been attempted before. This experiment is reaching its most dficult phase yet, the bit where the Government has to somehow let people start doing normal things ndash like going back to work and spending money to keep the economy going ndash while simultaneously reminding us that we wersquore not out of the woods yet. They have to encourage people to go out, while keeping them scared.Many ndash including me ndash have criticised politicians for their missteps and mixed messages over the last few months. But I also recognise a number of basic truths that itrsquos better to get onersquos head around sooner rather than later, regardless of party politics.The first is that until coronavirus has been completely eradicated around the world, risk is going to play a part in our lives for the foreseeable future. The second is closely related: the state cannot tell us exactly how to manage this risk in every single circumstance. We may get health advice and government guidance, but ultimately we have to navigate this new, more precarious world on our own.How we do this, and, crucially, how we feel about doing it, depends on many dferent things, of course, not least our age and underlying health, our financial situation and, to a signicant extent, our personality.I know there are some who believe that through lting lockdown restrictions politicians in Westminster and Holyrood are very deliberately handing over responsibility ndash and thus blame ndash to the public for what comes next. And there may be some truth to this. But come on, letrsquos get real.Accusations of ldquomaking it up as they go along are thrown around asthis was an insult rather than simply a fact describing the predicament governments everywhere find themselves in. How could it be otherwise given the extraordinary events of the last six months  And whatrsquos the alternative to us being public health guinea pigs  Staying at home forever Community levels of the virus in Scotland are now low and falling. Our hospitals lie empty. We have a test and trace system in place to ndash hopefully ndash crack down on infections. Meanwhile, wellbeing continues to suffer under the restrictions and hundreds of thousands of jobs hang in the balance. All of these things mean we can and should lt the lockdown. And lting restrictions means the vast majority of folkmust decide for themselves what level of risk they are comfortable contending with, taking into consideration how it might affect their family and community as well as their own personal circumstances.We can help ourselves along the way. Firstly by staying up to date ndash through trusted, legitimate scientic and public information sources ndash about how the virus is transmitted and the best ways to stay safe.We can also resist the temptation to judge others for their decisions. Frankly, Irsquom sick of the army of armchair virologists spouting their culture war vitriol on social media. On one side you have those who seem to relish the lockdown, the class swots who shout too loudly about how they follow every part of the guidanceand seem to revel in the idea of a second wave. On the other side, you have the virus deniers. Both groups peddle fear and misinformation, whether that is their intention or not.At the end of the day none of us, not even the scientists, know whether and when there will be another wave of the virus. Uncertainty permeates through every part of our lives now, and we must find ways to live with and even embrace thiswe are to make it through the tough months ahead. Letrsquos at least try to respect each otherrsquos dferent ways of coping, shall we All columnists are free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: POLITICS WATCH    Guess who is taking on Mrs Thatcher s role as backseat driver
story: Margaret Thatcher reckoned she had been a ldquovery good backseat driver after John Major took her perch. He saw it dferently, calling her interventions ldquointolerable.The Thatcher-Major tussle was something of an exception, with most past leaders taking care not to criticise from the sidelines. Yet the rules, as well as being unwritten, are fluid. Mr Major himself threatened to take Boris Johnson to court for proroguing parliament.Tony Blair has fast become the past premier most likely to pop up with ldquohelpful advice, as he showed on Sky Newsrsquos Ridge on Sunday.With the BBC Sunday programmes now on their summer hols, presenter Sophy Ridge made the most of being the only show in town, breezing straight in on the dayrsquos big story ndash the sudden imposition of a fortnightrsquos quarantine for holidaymakers ing from Spain. Among those caught out by the rule change was Englandrsquos Transport Secretary, Grant Shapps.Jon Ashworth, Shadow Health Secretary, called the Governmentrsquos performance ldquoshambolic."There are holidaymakers in Spain at the moment confused and distressed, there are people about to go on holiday to Spain and the islands like Tenere who are confused, and they dont know whether their employers will allow them to take two weeks quarantine. The Government is just saying, We hope that employers co-operate. I hope I win the lottery on Saturday but that doesnt mean it is going to happen.Dominic Raab, the Foreign Secretary, was a hasty addition to the line-up. On a typical Sunday, Ridge has to make do with grabbing pavement interviews with Ministers when they are on their way to The Andrew Marr Show. This time, Mr Raab was live in the studio, at the requisite two metre social distance.No worker following quarantine guidance should be penalised by employers, he said, including by being put onto sick pay."If someone is following the law in relation to quarantine and self-isolating the way they should, they cant have penalties taken against them."As for his ministerial colleague Mr Shapps being caught on the hop, the Foreign Secretary said it showed the risks for everyone.Mr Raab could not guarantee other countries would follow Spain and be taken off the ldquosafe list."All we can say is weve got this Joint Biosecurity Centre, we monitor the risk in real time, we take decisive swt action and so there is an element of uncertainty this summerpeople go abroad. He will be staying at home over the recess.Tony Blair had the sun-smooched visage of the international globetrotter. Either that or he has been spending a lot of time in one of his back gardens. The latter seems unlikely given how busy he seems to be with the modestly titled Tony Blair Institute for Global Change. Its latest position paper, Learning to Live Alongside Covid-, was ostensibly the reason for his latest appearance.It was a wide-ranging interview covering everything from Russia and China to Scottish independence. You can read what he had to say in full where in the paper, but in summary: Boris Johnson was uselessScottish Labour had been uselessand current Labour leader Keir Starmer was proving usefulIt was fairly predictable stuff for the former Prime Minister, except for the end when Ridge asked why he could not seem to wrench himself away from politics. Isnrsquot it time to take a break, she wondered, go round the golf course or to the shepherdrsquos hut  David Cameron famously opted for the latter, spending a cool pound, on one for his Cotswolds garden.Mr Blair seemed momentarily taken aback. ldquoItrsquos not something I want to do. A lot of people might think thatrsquos exactly what he should do, stop talking about things. But I care about the country, I think we are at a huge moment of change in the world.Addressing the elephant backseat passenger in the room, he went on: ldquoIrsquove tried to do something that previous prime ministers have not done, but in the future I predict that many more will try and do because you leave office when yoursquove still got a lot of years of active working le.ldquoI always say to peopleyou donrsquot want to listen to me itrsquos a free world, donrsquot bother."But Irsquom not going to be playing rounds of golf or sitting twiddling my thumbs. Thatrsquos not going to happen ever.One was reminded of what Mrs Thatcher said after the  election, that she hoped to ldquogo on and on.Keir Starmer will be delighted.

title: all-inclusive-holidays-bit-naff
story: AFTER the hell of Covid  and all its nasty ramications, you need a real look-forward-to holiday now more than ever. OK, it wonrsquot be the same as in previous years, butyoursquore within the confines of an enclosed resort thatrsquos doing everything possible to keep you safe, it carries fewer risks than most holidays. So, for an autumn or winter break Irsquod recommend an all-inclusive. When it comes to that category, Sandals is the clear winner when what you need is to fly off to a sunny island with blue skies, glorious sunshine, white beaches, azure water and friendly locals.Jamaica fits the bill perfectly and, as a resort, Sandals Negril Beach Resort  Spa makes it all so darned easy. Yes, I know this company has in the past been guilty of cheesy adverts showing perfect couples schmoozing, and yoursquove probably heard rumours that all-inclusives are boring and sometimes the quality of food and drink is dubious, but in this instance none of that is the case. Quite the reverse.You find a mix of all age-groups there ndash just not families. Andyoursquore worried about Jamaica being unsafe, outside of Kingston yoursquore absolutely fine and within the resort yoursquore in a -star cocoon, guarded night and day, so you can relax.Well, yes, you are in a little bubble, but whatrsquos the harm in that for a week or so  Andyou want to explore Jamaica there are plenty excursions on offer.As a way to totally unwind and let someone  do all the hard work, therersquos nothing to beat it. In Sandals the quality of accommodation, food, drink, service and entertainment is truly -star. Their % repeat business ratio says it all.This particular resort sits on the western tip of the island about  miles from Montego Bayrsquos Sangster International Airport, fronting the northern end of Seven Mile Beach with a large roped-off area for safe swimming and views of a small offshore islet.Just north of Sandals is the infamous Hedonism II resort, where nude bathingare on public display. Geography canrsquot be big on their school curriculum though, so we took particular pleasure enlightening a few of them that Scotland is not in England and that the UK consists of four countries. Once we got through the Braveheart and Rangers Celtic stereotypes we were off and away.Personal butlers are at your beck and call in many of the suites. Just use your Sandals mobile phone so you can reach them at all hours should you need anything. Ours were brilliant and always went the extra mile . Before yoursquore even awake theyrsquoll have reserved your favourite spot by the pool or on the beach and laid out your large fluffy towels, a chill box with drinks, and a parasol. During the day theyrsquoll proffer more drinks and snacks, and evenyour restaurant of choice is full for dinner, theyrsquoll somehow find you a table. If you didnrsquot pack the greying undies and fancy a bit of lsquohow the other half liversquo theyrsquoll even unpack for you.Almost all the activities take place on the beachfront and in the four poolsThe resort is well-adapted for those wanting silence with a book or those annoying people who take part in every activity from water volleyball to the After Lunch General Knowledge Quiz .Watersport afficianados have everything from kayaks to Hobie cats and snorkelling gear ndash all included with your stay. Certied ers can head out on two daily trips for no additional fee and you can also get your PADI certication during your vacation here, for an additional cost.Among the other included activities are knee-boarding and water-skiing, glass-bottom boat trips and snorkelling excursions. Other activities include basketball, croquet and shuffleboard, and therersquos also a fitness centre and volleyball courts.The resort puts on a range of nightly entertainment ndash reggae parties, Burlesque nights and the like ndash so you can ldquogo out every night,you like, without ever leaving the property.Post show time is generally spent at the piano bar or chilling around a fire pit overlooking the beach.There are numerous options for accommodation. Even the basic rooms are lovely with rainfall showers, four-poster beds and marble bathrooms. Spend a bit more and you get lots more space, oceanfront views, outdoor soaking tubs and extra luxuries like butler service.With seven restaurants and five bars spread across the property, and room service from am-pm, therersquos plenty iety. The Bayside Restaurant is the main buffet restaurant, with a wide selection of fresh salads, grilled meats and seafood for breakfast and lunch .Cucina Romana is a romantic Italian restaurant fronting the beach. And when you just want a good old burger, excellent jerk chicken or some wings, therersquos the casual Beach Bistro, with a dine-in bar and several tables perched right over the beach.The pool bars are popular during the day, and theres a beachfront bar for evenings. For a change you can take the resortrsquos shuttle to Beaches ndash another resort owned by Sandals. Among its dining options is the impressive excellent sushi spot, Soy.Island Routes Caribbean Adventures is the in-house sightseeing company. We splashed out on their catamaran excursion and it was an excellent choice. Itrsquos a fun way to spend the afternoon and see a lot of the island without enduring the winding roads, traffic jams . Swim, snorkel, eat lunch and quaff a rum punch as you watch or join in with the crazy clf jumpers at Rickrsquos Cafeacute.You may be worrying about booking with all the upheavals going on, but Sandals have come up with the deal below which gives you protection under the Package Travel Regulationswhen you book a flight inclusive package with the UK tour operator Unique Caribbean Holidays via the Sandals call centre. title: Opinion  Rosemary Goring  We can all help regenerate Scotland  39 s wild lands
story: The guilt many of us feel for the part wersquove played in environmental calamity can be paralysing. Therersquos a general acceptance that, rather than sharing culpability with previous generations, we are the ones at whose door it can be laid. Obviously there is a lot of truth in that, as we continue to consume oceans of gas and oil, and despoil the seas with plastic. Yet the culprits for harming nature and tipping it out of kilter can be found in centuries past as well as in the international departure lounges of our airports. We should not shoulder all the blame.Irsquom thinking, as one example in my own backyard, of James V. For all his qualities as a leader he was never as impressive as his father James IV, or even his daughter Mary Queen of Scots. Quite apart from his military deficiencies at the Battle of Solway Moss, James V is the man who introduced , sheep into the Ettrick Valley, to raise money for his ambitious plans. In so doing, he destroyed the ancient Ettrick Forest, in which he and other royals had hunted and killed stags by the barrowload. The kingrsquos flocks arrived a some point after , and it did not take them long to strip the valley of its trees. By our own times, all that was left of this magnicent haven for wildle was a handful of thorn trees and birches. The rest is empty scrubland.I learned about this vandalous act in a newly published collection of essays called A Journey in Landscape Restoration: Carrran Wildwood and Beyond, edited by the biologists Philip and Myrtle Ashmole. Unlike most of the books I read this is not about the past, but about the future. There are almost as many photos as words, but the ones that most vividly illustrate the tale are those taken of the Carrran Valley, in the hills near Moffat.At the end of last century, this was a bleak expanse of severely depleted upland, grazed almost to extinction. A winter photo from  shows it as a dreary unrelieved desert: think of a chocolate brownie and yoursquod be close, though dusted with snow rather than icing sugar. Now, after  years of dedicated work by volunteers, it is growing lush once more. Swathes of native woodland clothe the hillsides, and its increasingly rich undergrowth is attracting an abundance of birds, insects, flowers, fungi and amphibians. The range of moths alone is heart-warming. As before and after images go, the dference could hardly be more striking.Previously you would have been lucky to hear much more than a grouse cackling, or watch a buzzard circling overhead now it is like the RSNO, as a sorts of birdle, from meadow pippits to willow warblers, wrens and winchats, strike up from the branches of native trees: birch, aspen, ash, oak, willow, rowan, hazel, Scots pine and juniper.In a series of pithy pieces,  of those who helped bring about this transformation describe how they went about it. Philip Ashmole originally had the idea to recreate an area of woodland in the Borders that replicated how it would have been before humans arrived. Out of this notion the Wildwood Group was established, which later formed itself into the Borders Forest Trust. On Millennium Day, the trust took ownership of the Carrran Valley, and set to work on creating a wildwood.In subsequent years, other ecological restoration schemes were also begun, at Corehead and Devilrsquos Beef Tub, and Talla and Gameshope. Together these groundbreaking ventures began to restore an area they have named The Wild Heart of Southern Scotland. Inspired by their example, others are now following their lead across the country.Living as I do in one of the great medieval sheep rearing districts of the Borders, in the vicinity of Melrose Abbey, itrsquos not hard to see the effect  and more years of grazing have had on the landscape. As one of the contributors to this book writes, sheep are engrained in our economy and culture, and they are the main reason, along with other herbivores such as voles, deer, goats and rabbits, why native woodland planting is rare: ldquoItrsquos no mystery: sheep eat trees. As flocks expanded, their predators ndash wolves and lynx ndash were killed, so that today other grazers, and especially deer, roam and breed without any natural check.The Borders Forest Trustrsquos vision was aided by bodies like the Forestry Commission and Scottish Natural Heritage, but its core remained a motivated army of volunteers. Many of these came with scientic credentials ndash geographers, botanists, ornithologists, ecologists and such like. Others were simply determined to help re-establish wilderness in barren terrain. One weekend last autumn,  members of the Glasgow branch of Extinction Rebellion arrived at Gameshope, and in two days helped plant , trees. In the words of Anna Craigen, the trustrsquos work would been impossible without volunteers: ldquoThey are our muscles, brains, eyes, dirty hands and the true heart of the Wild Heart.What is so uplting about this story is not just the determination and imagination of those who have made all this happen, but the tangible evidence of the regeneration they have promoted. Page after page of A Journey in Landscape Restoration is filled with photos of wildle now thriving in Carrran.Amid the bad news headlines about climate change, and images of bush fires, floods and landslides, it is good to be reminded of the things being done to turn the tide. Work such as that in Carrran Wildwood not only restores nature to its rightful state, but gives a terric boost to our own depleted sense of hope.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: gardening-dave-allan-tidying-soft-fruit-harvest
story: Nature can always get on without our help.A self-sown blackcurrant quite near our fruitcage is left to its own devices and thrives magnicently, spreading metres in every direction. I even have to trim some branches back from a burnside path. Like all our bushes this year, it was laden with fruit.But the berries were tiny, unlike the plump ones on its cultivated parent or the long, burgeoning strings on our ancient, th century redcurrant at the bottom of the garden.Regular pruning over the years has paid idends and kept us well supplied with delicious redcurrant wine.For starters, keeping a bush healthy is vital. Whatever the age or type of plant, the first step is to remove dying and poorly fruiting branches.And be sure to give strawberries a good haircut ndash no lockdown restrictions here. Use secateurs to remove all this yearrsquos foliage and old fruiting stems, leaving a bare -cm high crown. Fresh leaves emerge within a week or two -ndash promise!You also ensure good health by keeping fruit bushes well-shaped. So remove spindly little branches emerging in the centre. Aim for a goblet design, with  or  main branches forming a perimeter round an open centre.But keep an eye out for stronger young branches that yoursquoll need to replace old ones.Let a newcomer grow on for a year or two before making the change.Remove any inward-facing stems. And since the main branches should be fan-shaped, remove any crossing and touching stems. Shorten branch and stemby up to one third, particularly those growing downwards.Fresh stems from the base of trained cordon and fan-shaped fruit should also be removed, and prune to maintain the basic shape. With fans, cut back laterals to the desiredand similarly with cordons.Redcurrants and gooseberries fruit on mature wood, so the more of that you remove, the smaller next yearrsquos crop will beBlackcurrants fruit on one year old as well as mature wood, so remove two thirds of older branches to allow for a larger proportion of fresh ones.For a good crop, always retain one third of the mature wood.The raspberry family, including loganberries, Tayberries and the rest, behave quite dferently and, with the exception of autumn raspberries, only fruit on fresh canes or branches. So cut all fruited stems down to ground level.With rasps, aim for six of the strongest stems for next year. So, to ensure against any possible winter damage, select the eight or nine strongest ones, loosely tying them to the wires.Autumn raspberries are pruned at the end of winter, harvesting from fresh canes.When removing old canes in February, you could retain two or three and they would produce fruit in summer.This is possibleyoursquore limited for space. Otherwise, grow both types of plant and remove all fruited canes annually.With bush raspberries, cut out all the old stems to prevent congestion: thriving plants produce a prodigious young forest every year and that too needs thinning.And never clip soft fruit bushes like a hedge or simply shorten raspberry canes.To my horror, someone I know did this to an autumn iety one summer and wondered why she had no crop.Late summer early autumn pruning helps maintain healthy, well-shaped plants and while it improves the quality of next yearrsquos harvest, you get larger gooseberries by shortening fruiting spurs in early spring.But a few soft fruit bushes, like blueberries need virtually no pruning.Plant of the weekHyssop, Hyssopus officinalis, bears deep blue flowers with prominent stamens that are attractive to all sorts of bees. The aromatic foliage has culinary uses. Dead head and in March prune back to shape or clip for low hedging.

story: TO holiday or not to holiday  That is the question. Deciding whether or not to leave the country for the summer has turned into the Hokey Cokey. In, out. In, out. Donrsquot bother shaking it all about. Luckily, Diary contributors are always on vacation. They never stop taking a break from sensible behaviour and logical thought. Instead, they act like a bunch of proper dafties, as these classic tales from our archives prove. For instance, a reader once asked why doesnrsquot the United Nations declare Scotland a No Midge zone Yoursquove been framedTHE scene was a Glasgow court, where the accused vehemently denied a charge of shoplting. The problem, as is often the case, was that the prosecution had a videotape showing quite clearly the accused in the act of purloining the goods in question. The accused watched the video which, incontrovertibly, showed footage of him stuffing items up his jook.He appeared despondent.Suddenly he cheered up considerably and even leapt to his feet in elation.ldquoLook, he cried. ldquoI put the stuff back.ldquoNaw, son. Wersquore just rewinding the tape, said the court officer.Mind your languageWE once heard of a Glaswegian called Pat Rice, who moved to Dundee. story: FORMER primary school teacher Amy Kinnaird from Ochiltree was once driving some pupils to a swimming competition. title: opinion-kevin-mckenna-snp-needs-dump-middle-class-mediocrity
story: ldquoWe donrsquot want too many of the hoi-polloi sticking their noses in and interrupting the flannel. Next thing you know theyrsquoll be agitating for radical solutions to unemployment and health inequality in their wretched communities. And we canrsquot be having that while wersquore trying to push through Named Persons and Offensive Behaviour legislation or our Gender theories and our new Hate Bill. The poor dears just wouldnrsquot be able to understand what wersquore trying to do. Such entitled arrogance was typied this week by the hysterical and childish Twitter response of Humza Yousaf, alumnus of Hutchesonsrsquo Grammar in Glasgow, to reasonable criticism of his sinister and incoherent Hate Crime bill.Research conducted by The Herald in  showed that MSPs were five times more likely than the average Scot to be privately educated. Among the rest, the triumph of party hacks and the professional middle-classes is dismally apparent.Nowhere is the dread hand of middle-class complacency more apparent than in the Scottish Government. The SNP cabinet reads like the staff register for Classic FM. Each one has a degree and several have multiple parchments, including one who seems to have been competing with Jim Murphy for the title of Scotlandrsquos student prince.Earlier this year, the academics Michael Keating and Paul Cairney in an article first published by the Centre for Constitutional Change maintained that the hegemony of the political elites at Westminster has been replicated at Holyrood. It built on general themes the pair had previously explored in a paper published in . Keating and Cairney concluded that among MSPs ldquoa common middle-class background predominated. ldquoMany such occupations ndash such as in law or education ndash were once described as politics facilitating because they offered the skills or connections conducive to seeking election.Their observations reflected research conducted by University College London in  that examined the policy preferences of working-class and career politicians within the Labour Party both before and during Tony Blairs tenure as leader. It showed that working-class MPs were much more in favour of traditional welfare policies than their careerist colleagues. This had contributed greatly during the Blair era towards more centrist polices around reforming welfare and a much diminished representation of working-class voters interests. ldquoPut bluntly, said the reportrsquos author, ldquocareerist MPs are much more likely to blow with the political winds.The SNP, it seems, is modelling itself on Mr Blairrsquos New Labour principles. In a remarkable and detailed essay written by George Kerevan earlier this month, the former SNP politician excoriated the party for its cultivation of Big Business and a ruthless party machine driving a byzantine bureaucracy than can only be traversed by favoured acolytes and savants whorsquove been given the secret passwords.Itrsquos not now enough to have supported the SNP and fought for independence all of your adult le to be deemed fit for a party nomination. You are also expected to defer to the esoteric cult of political fetishists gaining influence in the party.Stepping into this circle is Chris McEleny, who announced on Thursday that he is seeking to become the SNPrsquos candidate in Inverclyde at next yearrsquos Scottish Parliament elections. I wish him well but I donrsquot envy him. If he emerges unscathed and successful from the partyrsquos vetting procedures the task of facing down the unionist parties will be a breeze in comparison.Mr McEleny is an authentic, working-class tradesman from Greenock who has led the SNP group on Inverclyde Council with some distinction. The SNP high command though, have made it clear they donrsquot want people like him anywhere near their salons and boutiques. Recently he was attacked ndash in adolescent manner ndash by Alyn Smith in an article that recalled Denis Healeyrsquos famous observation about Geoffrey Howe and dead sheep. Later he attracted the petulant wrath of Pete Wishart for insisting that the SNP be a little more, you know hellip pro-active in the independence department. Smith and Wishart are tame party courtiers: desperate to please the leadership less so in constructing a route towards independence.McElenyrsquos experience at the hands of party managers is broadly similar to that of Chris Stephens, another authentic, working-class activist who did more than anyone to persuade some of Scotlandrsquos trade unions to transfer their allegiances to the SNP from Labour. Yet only after more than a decade of rejection did the SNP deign to let him compete at the  election.Mr McEleny has been subjected to a campaign of intimidation and harassment carrying the stamp of the party hierarchy and carried out by an insidious pack of jackals on social media. Everything from his Catholic faith his criticism of GRA reforms his admiration for Joanna Cherry and his inconveniently persistent calls for an independence Plan B has been subject to abuse from the SNPrsquos secret police.In recent months his has been a lone voice pleading for an emergency economic aid package for Inverclyde, home to Scotlandrsquos poorest neighbourhood. Coronavirus death and infection rates in Inverclyde are three times higher than the national average and Mr McEleny has been this communityrsquos most eloquent advocate.Not possessing a degree and being a manual worker he would be an exotic creature inside the Holyrood party. And possessing such views as he does also makes him the wrong type of nationalist for the SNP in the same way that Joanna Cherry is the wrong sort of feminist.If the SNP persists with its aggressive obsession with rewriting the rules on human biology and their latest attempts to criminalise the Scottish population they will make themselves unelectable, no matter what the rosy opinion polls currently suggest. They are fast becoming the biggest threat to the prospect of an independent Scotland. The party needs more people of Chris McElenyrsquos stamp to steer it away from these self-indulgent caprices.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions.
